And people still forgetting the stanzas that 87% of the entire Congress agreed with the intel that was presented to the President. If people are going to play the music, they should play the song in its entirety. Now, where is that "Beating a Dead Horse" smilie thing? There's a substantial difference between suspecting a country is developing WMD and sending a nation to war over that suspicion. I keep hearing the right saying “Clinton thought they had WMD”…Clinton didn’t invade. “The Congress thought they had WMD”…congress didn’t invade. “Germany and France thought they had WMD”…Germany and France didn’t invade. The question was did the administration lie to the congress and the American people to justify its desire to go to war; I guess we have our answer. You think this whole thing is a joke? Watch where this leads. Whether or not he lied, there is no real proof, however all I need to know is that he did state the Ousting of Sadam was intrigal to the WOT seemingly thinking it being more of a moderate Muslim country, it would be a staging ground for additional WOT actions. So all the other sh*T aside, Iraq was part of his WOT strategy, WMDs or not. I didn't support the invasion of Iraq, even though I was sent there, but after it started I coldn't just NOT do my job. I also supported the war after because not to do so would only hurt our brothers and sisters still over there. Even if invading Iraq as part of the WOT was valid, IMO it was NOT it was at best a destraction, the way the occupation was handled caused a LOT more problems for the US in the WOT than any POSSIBLE advantage that could have been gained from the invasion. I won't argue that, like I said, I was searching for OBL in A-Stan and then all of a sudden came up on orders to Iraq. We thought he must have jumped ship to Iraq, most of us didn't understand what the hell was going on, that said, we knew we had to go. Todays politics remind me of an old saying. - "Ideas are more powerful than guns. We would not let our enemies have guns, why should we let them have ideas?" - Joseph Stalin

content: Senator Rockfeller is contradicting his own reports and his own vote in 2003 to go to war. It's been a while but the report made by his co-chairmanship that AQ were suspected of being in Salman Park but couldn't confirm. While they did have knowledge with dual confirmation of others from Yemen, Somalia, Chechnya, and many other Arab states attended the site gaining insight on Bio/Chemical weapons sponsored and hosted by the Hussein regime. It's always been my contention when someone attacks their neighbors, fundamentally uses resources to divide the UN, NATO and westerner alliance with mideast countries, sponsoring terrorist in Lebanon, Palestine, Egypt, they are picking a fight. Throw the attempted assassination of a past President, no matter of you like his politic's or not, give reasons to confront the antagonist. Iran on the other hand gives additional reasons for completely separate them from the civilized world. In either case, as long as the regimes continuation of a policies adverse to the area there will be no peace in the middle east. Iraq is joining the world community. That alone might not prove the war worth to some, but allowing generations of Husseins along with theocracy in Iran for unseeable future controlling the world energy had to be broken. History will make it note worthy. "http://intelligence.senate.gov/phaseiiaccuracy.pdf

content: quote: Originally posted by rayevinsonsr: Senator Rockfeller is contradicting his own reports and his own vote in 2003 to go to war. "http://intelligence.senate.gov/phaseiiaccuracy.pdf The first Senate Report, under a Republican Chairmen, catagorically stated that Salman Pak was not a terrorist training camp, and certainly had nothing to do with Al Qaeda. From the 2004 Report quote: -Reporting about Activity at Salman Pak m)The Salman Pak facility outside Baghdad was an unconventional warfare training facility used by the 11s and Saddam Hussein’s Fedayeen troops to train its officers for counterterrorism operations against regime opponents. The facility contained a village mockup for urban combat training and a derelict commercial aircraft. Iraqi Support for Terrorism explained that uncorroborated reports since 1999 have alleged “that Baghdad has sponsored a variety of conventional and mostly rudimentary instruction for al-Qa’ida at the Salman Pak Unconventional Warfare Training Facility outside Baghdad.” The -reports came from fit hat “training at this camp includes paramilitary exercises, such as running long distances daily and self-defense tactics.” Iraqi Support for Terrorism also stated, “these reports are part of a larger body of reporting over the past decade that ties Salman Pak to Iraqi surrogate groups.” The Committee was not provided with reports that showed that Iraq trained Palestinian extremist groups and other Arabs of various nationalities at the Salman Pak facility for potential surrogate terror operations. However, a senior CIA analysts stated “We had [sources] talking about Salman Pak and training at Salman Pak and funding for Palestinian groups.” The CIA did not rule out the possibility that Iraq trained known al-Qaida operatives or could have trained an Arab al-Qaida member without having knowledge that the terrorist was an al-Qaida member. m) m)In Iraqi Supportfor Terrorism, the CIA provided additional explanation of the sources of the information, noting that, “press and =reporting about al-Qa’ida activity at Salman Pak determined, “that at least one =defectod, whose story appeared in Vanity Fair magazine, surged after 11 September.” The CIA had embellished and exaggerated his access.” Additionally, other sources only repeated information provided by the defector, and also lacked first-hand access to the information. Committee staff asked both CIA and DIA analysts whether any al-Qaida operatives or other sources have confirmed Salman Pak training allegations, and the unanimous response was that none have reported knowledge of any training. A DIA analyst told Committee staff, “The Iraqi National Conmess tINCl has been Dushing information for a long time about Salman Pak and training of al-Qa'ida

It's been a while but the report made by his co-chairmanship that AQ were suspected of being in Salman Park but couldn't confirm. While they did have knowledge with dual confirmation of others from Yemen, Somalia, Chechnya, and many other Arab states attended the site gaining insight on Bio/Chemical weapons sponsored and hosted by the Hussein regime. It's always been my contention when someone attacks their neighbors, fundamentally uses resources to divide the UN, NATO and westerner alliance with mideast countries, sponsoring terrorist in Lebanon, Palestine, Egypt, they are picking a fight. Throw the attempted assassination of a past President, no matter of you like his politic's or not, give reasons to confront the antagonist. Iran on the other hand gives additional reasons for completely separate them from the civilized world. In either case, as long as the regimes continuation of a policies adverse to the area there will be no peace in the middle east. Iraq is joining the world community. That alone might not prove the war worth to some, but allowing generations of Husseins along with theocracy in Iran for unseeable future controlling the world energy had to be broken. History will make it note worthy. "http://intelligence.senate.gov/phaseiiaccuracy.pdf

"http://intelligence.senate.gov/phaseiiaccuracy.pdf The first Senate Report, under a Republican Chairmen, catagorically stated that Salman Pak was not a terrorist training camp, and certainly had nothing to do with Al Qaeda. From the 2004 Report quote: -Reporting about Activity at Salman Pak m)The Salman Pak facility outside Baghdad was an unconventional warfare training facility used by the 11s and Saddam Hussein’s Fedayeen troops to train its officers for counterterrorism operations against regime opponents. The facility contained a village mockup for urban combat training and a derelict commercial aircraft. Iraqi Support for Terrorism explained that uncorroborated reports since 1999 have alleged “that Baghdad has sponsored a variety of conventional and mostly rudimentary instruction for al-Qa’ida at the Salman Pak Unconventional Warfare Training Facility outside Baghdad.” The -reports came from fit hat “training at this camp includes paramilitary exercises, such as running long distances daily and self-defense tactics.” Iraqi Support for Terrorism also stated, “these reports are part of a larger body of reporting over the past decade that ties Salman Pak to Iraqi surrogate groups.” The Committee was not provided with reports that showed that Iraq trained Palestinian extremist groups and other Arabs of various nationalities at the Salman Pak facility for potential surrogate terror operations. However, a senior CIA analysts stated “We had [sources] talking about Salman Pak and training at Salman Pak and funding for Palestinian groups.” The CIA did not rule out the possibility that Iraq trained known al-Qaida operatives or could have trained an Arab al-Qaida member without having knowledge that the terrorist was an al-Qaida member. m) m)In Iraqi Supportfor Terrorism, the CIA provided additional explanation of the sources of the information, noting that, “press and =reporting about al-Qa’ida activity at Salman Pak determined, “that at least one =defectod, whose story appeared in Vanity Fair magazine, surged after 11 September.” The CIA had embellished and exaggerated his access.” Additionally, other sources only repeated information provided by the defector, and also lacked first-hand access to the information. Committee staff asked both CIA and DIA analysts whether any al-Qaida operatives or other sources have confirmed Salman Pak training allegations, and the unanimous response was that none have reported knowledge of any training. A DIA analyst told Committee staff, “The Iraqi National Conmess tINCl has been Dushing information for a long time about Salman Pak and training of al-Qa'ida
